title: When will Paul Ryan formally endorse Donald Trump for president?
possible_answers: At or after the Republican National Convention
preds: I was right. Has it at 90% before the convention. Updated to 100 now. Knew Paul Ryan wouldn't hold out forever. I guess party unity is more important that possibly electing a "oh my god" a dirty democrat.
Well that party is full of gutless sycophants.  Hillary and Bernie are fighting over minimal differences.   While every one on the other side rally's around a man who is not a republican?
He may not have used the actual word, but all signals now point to Ryan's endorsement of Trump's candidacy.

Paul Ryan endorses Donald Trump
CNN - 1h ago

Should close now. The lamest endorsement ever, it is still described as such by every media outlet out there.
Agree it probably happened. We'll see, but back-dated of course. http://www.nytimes.com/2016/06/03/us/politics/paul-ryan-donald-trump.html?_r=0

Paul Ryan just announced that "he would vote for Donald Trump."  I guess that counts as an endorsement.

More  GOP unity in the face of Democratic disunity ? If Ryan votes for DT, when will he endorse him?

Date: 2. Juni 2016 um 21:14:58 MESZ Breaking News: House Speaker Paul Ryan says he will vote for Donald Trump; 'confident' he'll turn House GOP agenda into law - GazetteXtra House Speaker Paul Ryan says he will vote for Donald Trump; 'confident' he'll turn House GOP agenda into law - GazetteXtra http://bit.ly/1VzNWng "...Through these conversations, I feel confident he (Trump) would help us turn the ideas in this agenda into laws to help improve people's lives. That's why I'll be voting for him this fall,” Ryan wrote. Ryan goes on to say that he and Trump do not agree on everything and that when he sees the need, Ryan will continue to speak his mind. “But the reality is, on the issues that make up our agenda, we have more common ground than disagreement,” Ryan wrote...0

Ryan has his real sights on the 2020 (or 2024) Presidential run. It is why he is not running in 2016 and will not be drafted as an alternative. The Electoral College will be a formidable wall that Trump will need to overcome. It is unlikely.  Given that, Ryan is much better off in the eyes of history not giving his formal endorsement to a crackpot and business-bully. I don't see Bush or Romney ever giving their endorsements. Why would Ryan capitulate for a short-term atta-boy, only to be pilloried later.
Paul will come around just before the convention.

Self explanatory. ANOTHER GOP heavy weight falls into line attempting to show unity in the face of the Democratic lack thereof + Server/Email Gate which acts as another voter disincentive or cross over potential. Adding to question - just how long will it take for Paul Ryan to show MORE GOP UNITY?
Date: 1. Juni 2016 um 17:47:55 MESZ Subject: McConnell says Trump has earned Republican nomination - The Portland Press Herald / Maine Sunday Telegram http://www.pressherald.com/2016/05/31/mcconnell-says-trump-has-earned-republican-nomination/
"...WASHINGTON – Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell said Tuesday that while presumptive Republican presidential nominee Donald Trump is “a phenomenon” and political outsider, he has earned the right to the GOP nomination and the party’s support..." IN THE OTHER HAND, Ryan says "he is not ready"...
Date: 1. Juni 2016 um 17:58:04 MESZ Subject: House Speaker Paul Ryan: Not Ready To Endorse Donald Trump - News - KFGO The Mighty 790 AM | Fargo ND, Moorhead MN http://kfgo.com/news/articles/2016/may/31/house-speaker-paul-ryan-not-ready-to-endorse-donald-trump/
decreasing on account that it hasn't happened yet :)

House Speaker Ryan is currently very popular among the Republicans, and he has voiced his objections about Trump in the past. Because of Ryan's popularity among his own party members, I think he will resist an endorsement of Trump for as long as he can. Trump is already the presumptive Republican Presidential nominee, since Cruz and Kasich have withdrawn their campaigns. Thus, an endorsement will have to come eventually from Ryan, whether he likes it or not. I believe he will be under some pressure to endorse Trump near the Republican National Convention, because of the significance of the occasion. If he were to  wait till the general election approaches to endorse Trump, it will raise eyebrows as to why he did not do so earlier at the National Convention.
I think Ryan will make his endorsement at the convention, as he introduces Trump to accept the nomination of the Republican party.
Ryan expects Trump to lose and he wants a clear shot to run in 2020. He needs to be seen as a party man with a streak of independence.
The Speaker will schedule his spine-removal surgery for some time in June, I think--slightly later than the other lemmings but still in time for the Official Show of Unity in Cleveland.
Ryan - This is a process, but our first meeting went well. I think it depends on whether other Republicans can find another party candidate to run. I don't think they will be able to find anoth

NB: Increasing consistency ....b/w one time political enemies Marco Rubio ( now falling into line)... &, Paul Ryan's GOP "Further Down Road the Unity Path" Than Democrats" ( yet, to do so but probability increasing)... Date: 29. Mai 2016 um 20:24:47 MESZ Subject: Marco Rubio joins the Trump train. http://www.slate.com/blogs/the_slatest/2016/05/26/marco_rubio_joins_the_trump_train.html 1. Marco Rubio says he plans to attend the Republican convention, will release his delegates to vote for Donald Trump and would be willing to speak on Trump's behalf. "I want to be helpful. I don't want to  be harmful, because I don't want Hillary Clinton to be president," Rubio told CNN's Jake Tapper in an interview.
"Look, my policy differences with Donald Trump—I spent 11 months talking about them. So I think they're well understood," Rubio said. "That said ... I DON'T want Hillary Clinton to be president. If there's something I can do to help that from happening, and it's helpful to the cause, I'd most certainly be honored to be considered for that."
2. Ryan on GOP Further Down Unity Path Roan than Democrats http://www.newsmax.com/Politics/Paul-Ryan-Unity-GOP/2016/05/28/id/731235/

Date: 29. Mai 2016 um 13:22:12 MESZ
Subject: Paul Ryan on Trump: GOP 'Further Down the Unity Path' Than Democrats Hypothesis: Ryan NO longer dogmatically opposed to DT. Now, "seeking to get onto the same page" to "unify" GOP. Now, using "vague verbiage" as a prelude to argue he has for his interests negotiated a deal w/ DT for the best possible outcome for the Good of the Country from a GOP perspective.  NB:  Article simply supportive of hypothesis ...
http://www.newsmax.com/Politics/Paul-Ryan-Unity-GOP/2016/05/28/id/731235/ "...House Speaker Paul Ryan said Saturday that he and Donald Trump are STILL speaking about how to "get on the same page" when it comes to principles and policies the Republican Party can unify under, BUT insisted that Democrats and the ongoing battle between Hillary Clinton and Bernie Sanders for the party's presidential nomination are MUCH MORE divided..."

http://www.cnn.com/2016/05/26/politics/paul-ryan-donald-trump-gop/index.html
Ryan appears to require a unified party - although some of Trumps positions ( ex. Trade) may never match the GOP position.
He'll fall in line, but later rather than sooner.

Seems odds-on likely to happen at some point. I think it would be a great set-piece for the convention... obvious way to get journalists talking about the convention and talking about republican stuff is to leave open the hint of mystery... will he or won't he endorse at the convention? What's going to happen? Then a dramatic speech and reveal of party unity. That seems like a clearly useful scenario. I don't see much upside in resolving the matter before the convention. I don't see much downside in waiting for the scenario I described. Just speculating.

Date: 26. Mai 2016 um 18:26:59 MESZ Conclusion: NOT yet but, let's keep talking.  Subject: Tweet by Sabrina Siddiqui on Twitter, Journalist @ The Guardian  	Sabrina Siddiqui (@SabrinaSiddiqui)
26.05.16, 17:39
Paul Ryan says he and Donald Trump had "a very good and very productive phone call … I'll leave it at that."
Also : Tweet from : S. Siddidqui ""...Paul Ryan on not yet endorsing Trump: "What I'm most concerned about is making sure we have real party unity, not pretend party unity."

People seem overconfident that this will definitely happen.  http://www.businessinsider.com/paul-ryan-donald-trump-endorsement-2016-5 But I agree that it is very likely to happen (I imagine a tepid endorsement) and that if it does that it will happen before the convention.
It's too divisive to leave it much longer

Ryan will probably fall in line like the rest of his party after he makes his show of not supporting Trump for his own purposes.  As the chair of the convention, he probably can't avoid endorsing the nominee before the convention, so my guess is for before the convention, but it will be maybe just a few days before.
He seems more willing to support as others join, but most likely wait until the convention.
Up following crowd. Might be too late, but the question has not been active for many days. Probably the only way Ryan could avoid it would be to exit a convention role.

Date: 25. Mai 2016 um 12:56:01 MESZ Subject: Ryan Said to Tell Confidants He’s Ready to End Trump Standoff - Bloomberg Politics

A show of GOP UNITY sooner rather than later adds momentum to continuing Democratic DISUNITY? http://www.bloomberg.com/politics/articles/2016-05-25/ryan-said-to-tell-confidants-he-s-ready-to-end-trump-standoff Chances look good DT receives an extra boost from Ryan before Convention.

Looks like it might happen soon

http://abcnews.go.com/Politics/paul-ryan-endorse-trump-trump-senior-level-campaign/story?id=39356743
http://www.bloomberg.com/politics/articles/2016-05-25/ryan-said-to-tell-confidants-he-s-ready-to-end-trump-standoff

Ryan's relationship with Trump now seems cordial as the Republican establishment accepts reality. To maximise the beneficial theatre of his endorsement it would best come at the convention. This timing would also contrast Republican unity with what is likely to be a very acrimonious Democratic convention only a few days later.
Adjusting a bit now that consensus has changed.  FWIW http://www.politico.com/story/2016/05/off-message-paul-ryan-trump-could-win-223458

Given that most Republican office holders have endorsed Trump it is likely that Ryan will at some point before the election as well.  It's hard to assign probabilities, but I think he's going to hold out for a while to possibly bring Trump closer to his policy agenda and possibly provide cover for other representatives in competitive elections in districts where Trump does not poll well.

Wild guess.
Paul Ryan is a sociopath and a magician.  Donald Trump is more likely to hurt his career than to help it.  Ryan will try to avoid making new enemies for as long as possible, and he seems to have found a way to keep all sides at bay for now.  Pressure will mount at a few key moments during the campaign.  He may not be able to duck out of making an official decision, or getting noticed for not doing so, in those moments.  Then again, he's a magician.  He could easily surprise me.
I think he's playing chicken with Trump but realizes the political realities of not endorsing the party candidate.

This is a tough one for Paul Ryan.  He actually has a soul, a conscience, and actual conservative beliefs.  Donald Trump is anathema to Ryan.  Ryan cannot endorse Trump without selling his soul, killing his conscience, and negating everything he truly believes.  Ryan may, possibly, be somehow forced to this extreme, but as long as he holds his ground Trump has no power over him.

Paul Ryan is covering all his basis and he knows that the only way the Republicans can continue their underhanded way of hijacking and stealing elections is by formally endorsing him and then in the background go about the narrow view, special interest, politics that the party is famous for (e.g., anti migration, anti abortion, pro gun, etc.).
I heard someone say that Ryan just wants to be his VP.  I can buy that, but regardless, they're going to make up and it's not going to take that long.

Adjusting since Rs seem to be accepting inevitable faster than I anticipated. Still probably shouldn't be forecasting this question since I don't know how to differentiate between a weak and real endorsement ("formal" doesn't really help since any significant interview or news conference would be in that category).

He'll come around to endorsement, just a matter of when.  They've stated their previous meeting was productive (which if Ryan didn't intend to endorse, I think he would have been more negative about the meeting).  We have roughly 2 months before convention.  It'll probably happen before Trump is officially named the candidate, however, there is a good chance that Ryan withholds the endorsement to bring Trump back to the front page of the news if needed (Hillary, or Bernie, are getting all the coverage).

the party will not likely unit before the polls show trump can actually will. Congress will not get on the coattails until there is more visibility. there is a chance  he does not ever support him if it's clear he cannot win the general. most of congress will want no part of him. Ryan new to the job will likely follow the trend and only lead when its a clear win. if he backs him and looses bad he risks his job. most politicians wont risk their jobs for anything.
It's going to happen. The GOP is falling in to place. Or, better said, GOP is effectively being destroyed from within.
Ryan AND Trump need a dramatic start for the campaign ahead
Ryan will not go to the convention without endorsing Trump. He's too much of a GOP team player.
He will wait until the Convention, thus stressing his importance a leader of the Republican Party.

I don't think he'll ever give a glowing endorsement. I see it going down as something more like "I have a lot of concerns about Trump's policies and his character, and I think we may have trouble working together, but he's a much better option than Clinton and I think you should vote for him." If Ryan didn't endorse, it would likely harm him and the GOP, possibly significantly, at least in the short term. However, a lukewarm endorsement would seem to give freedom to congressional candidates in tough races to distance themselves from Trump. It also leaves him room later if Clinton wins to distance himself from Trump as he gears up for 2020.
Ryan will cave to Trump to avoid a fight at the convention.

For party unity's sake he has to, whether he wants to or not. I don't believe he is going to jeopardize being made responsible for a Clinton win, by dividing the party.
Therefore the questions seems to be before or at the convention. Most likely time is in the lead up to the convention, but it might also be directly at the convention in some kind of show, where DT acts all presidential.

He will at least weakly endorse at some point (because he basically has to). And the convention will be a forcing mechanism to do so. Most likely he will do so in the lead up to the convention, but perhaps he will do so at the convention itself. Not likely after though.

For the sake of his party and for his own interest to preserve his function of speaker of the house (that he will loose anyway?) : «Republicans have a limited window in which to hash out their disagreements. Some Trump supporters believe Mr. Ryan and others should fall in line behind the GOP alternative to Mrs. Clinton well before the party’s convention in late July.»
http://www.wsj.com/articles/donald-trump-meets-with-paul-ryan-other-republican-leaders-1463063702 «The dominoes are beginning to fall around Ryan. His two deputies — Majority Leader Kevin McCarthy of California and Majority Whip Steve Scalise of Louisiana — are both Trump supporters. Oregon Rep. Greg Walden — the chairman of the National Republican Congressional Committee — backed Trump Thursday shortly after the Ryan-Trump confab ended. Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell (R-Ky.) has already given Trump his support, even if it wasn't exactly a full-throated endorsement.» http://www.politico.com/story/2016/05/paul-ryan-donald-trump-meeting-223125#ixzz49K1te84z
Republican party needs to show it is united even though Trump is a bad presidential nominee for the party. Trump will tone down his wild, ridiculous statements and get the RNC behind him.
What choice does he have, if he wants a career? He's only ever had one career. Ultimately, he can't afford to offend the GOP.
He has to if he wants to keep Hillary from the White House.

Not to quibble, but what does "endorse" mean? How many are "voting (or supporting) for him," etc? What if WaPo takes that and says it is an "endorsement" with whatever qualifiers they want to use? That being said I suspect the Speaker will do something that is semi-supportive that pro-DT can read as endorse and anti can read as anyone but DT. At least by participating in this, my continued place in the bottom third more or less of this challenge will be ensured.
Opps read the question the wrong way...
Party will unite against Clinton.  Ryan will make the announcement close to but before the convention.  The convention itself will be rather sedate with Trump getting what he wants.
Paul Manafort is the mob enforcer of GOP politics.  betting he'll get Ryan to fall in line.

Paul Ryan is a principle-free shrimp. He will do what he is told. In this particular case, people who understand math will tell people who Paul will listen to that unity in GOP is the only chance GOP has in upcoming elections.
What would HR (Howard and Hank) do?
They need leverage before the main event to get him in line, then they will rally.
